## summary

::: {.container-col .incremental .center}
::: {.element2 .fragment}
native speakers of tonal languages are better, on average, at melodies
:::

::: {.element2 .fragment}
this advantage traded off with worse beat perception
:::

::: {.element2 .fragment}
robust across 19 different tonal languages, musical training, income, education, and other cultural predictors
:::
:::

## why?

::: {.container-col .incremental .center}
::: {.element .fragment}
pitch important for tonal languages = increased selective attention for pitch
:::

::: {.element .fragment}
increased selective attention for pitch = decreased selective attention to duration
:::

:::

## takeaways

::: {.container-col .incremental .center}
::: {.element .fragment}
culture can shape perception in a way that crosses domains
:::

::: {.element .fragment}
web-based citizen science is effective<br>for testing generalizability
:::
